div1.p: This article discusses mosquito control efforts in Panama around the Canal Zone.

div1.head: Article: The American Mosquito Extermination Society on Mosquito Work Going on at Panama, February 20, 1909
div1.p:
As this is a “Mosquito Extermination Society”, I wouldwill confine my remarks
to describing the mosquito work we have already done and that which we expect
to do.

The American Territory here extentds north and south for a distance of about
fifty miles, and being in width ten miles. The Canal is its centre through its
length, with the town of Colon at its northern extremity on the Carribean and
Panama its southern extremity on the Pacific. The line of the Canal runs from
north to south up the Chagres river and up the Obispo, one of the branches of the
Chagres, some thirty-five miles to the continental divide. It then descends
to the valley of the Rio Grande, some fifteen miles, to the Pacific. The country
is rolling, covered with tropical undergrowth, and very attractive in appearance; no
more swamp than we have along one of our small rivers in the hill country of New York.

In the town of Panama our attention is principally turned to the stegomyia
work. Our Inspectors go about the city methodically, in districts laid off, noting
the number of deposits of each breeding mosquito. At present there is no water-
supply in Panama and almost everybody has to depend upon collecting rain water.
The poor do this principally in barrels and containers of all sorts and descriptions.
This makes the town an ideal breeding place for the stegomyia. I recently had
examined one hundred mosquitoes, killed in one house, and eighty-one out of the
hundred were stegomyia. This is a very much larger proportion of stegomyia than
I ever found in Havana. The largest proportion I think I ever found there was
about twenty-ficve per cent. The town also at this time gets a good part of its water
supply from surface wells scattered all about the suburbs

Upon the report of these inspectors, tops orf wood and wire gauze are made for
all water barrels and cisterns, and wooden spigots put in all barrels. When this
has been entirely accomplished the breeding of stegomyia in the city will be
greatly decreased. At the present time we have about all the water barrels covered
and most of the cisterns oiled. In the suburbs we have most of the
-2-
oiled, and expect, as we are able, to drain many of them. The greater part of
our present mosquito work in Panama is devoted to the killing of adults.

During December and January we had some sixteen or seventeen cases of yellow
fever in the town. Up to the middle of January, as each case of yellow fever was
reported, we had been going to the house, fumigating that house and all contiguous
houses, and thus killing all the infected mosquitoes at that particular focus, as
had been done in Havana. But, wishing to get rid of yellow fever more expeditiously
than we had done there, we have now adopted the plan of going through the town
systematically and fumigating every house there. At this work we have at present
150 men pasting up houses and burning sulphur and pyrethrum. This mosquito work
is done entirely with regard to Yellow Fever. When we have yellow fever in a
place we know that we have had some infected adult mosquito. Now if we simply
depend upon preventing the development of mosquitoes we know that this yellow
fever will continue until the infected mosquitoes die a natural death. This might
be four or five months and, therefore, we have to adopt more expeditious methods.

Water is being brought in by pipe line from the head waters of the Rio Grande,
some ten miles and at the same time a sewer system is being put in and, when this is
downne, it is probable that the streets will be paved. This will, of course, greatly
decrease the necessity for our mosquito work. When we have a plentiful supply of
water we can prohibit the collection of rain water and enforce such prohibition.
Street paving will do away with most puddles and sewerage help in the seesame
direction.

At Colon we are trying the same work, but as most of the town is on piles in
a swamp, complete eradication is at present impossible, but by the end of another
year the town will have been filled in entirely some ten feet, a sewerage system
put in, streets paved and a water supply interest introduced. This, with very little
supervision, will settle the mosquito question there.

Along the line of the Canal is the hardest and most difficult problem we have
with regard to anopheles work. We have 300 men along this strip looking after
-3-
mosquito breeding in some twenty little towns. The water barrels are looked
after in the way described, but most of the work is devoted to superficial
drainage and ditching. It is hard to describe how much work has been
accomplished in the last eight months along these lines, but I think it fair
to attribute some of the present good health of our laboring force to these
measures, as they certainly did not exist formerly with the laboring force in the
same locality.

We had on our rolls on the first of February something over 6,000 men. Of
these 6,000 on the same date, 125 were in the hospital, a rate of about 2 per cent.
When we compare this with anything we know of in the former construction down here,
or even the health conditions at home in our Army and Navy, it wouldwill make a very
good showing.

With the employees brought from the United States we have been particularly
fortunate with regard to malaria, not having had a single death since we came down
in July, nearly eight months now, among this class of employees. We probably
have in the neighborhood of 700 white men from the United States. Up to the
first of this month we could say the same with regard to yellow fever, not a
single man of this class having died. So far this month (February), up to the
14th, in the whole Zone we have had only four cases of yellow fever. But one
of these was an American employee who died. Considering the circumstances, I
think our mosquito work is holding Yellow Fever very well in check, when we
consider that we are living within an old, crowded town of 20,000 inhabitants and in
one of the worst months of the year, to have only four cases within two weeks.

I look forward, in a very short time, to having the last infected female
stegomyia mosquito safely smothered in pyrathrum funes, and that means the
extinction of Yellow Fever on the Zone. Then all we will have to do will be to
keep a sharp watch and see that none is introduced from the outside, just as the
Cubans have done at Havana for the last three years; and surely we can do as well
as they. When that condition is reached Panama will be as safe as Havana, which
is all we ask, as far as yellow fever is concerned.
